chatgpt_double_star.new_statement: Abortion law should start from two widely shared aims: protect pregnant people from preventable harm and treat developing life with serious moral regard. That means guaranteeing prompt, safe care early in pregnancy under medical privacy, setting any later-stage restrictions around fetal viability and clinical realities, and writing clear, workable exceptions for threats to health, rape or incest, and lethal fetal diagnoses—without criminalizing patients or clinicians. Governments should also lower unintended pregnancy and hardship by expanding contraception access, comprehensive sex education, prenatal and postpartum care, and practical supports like childcare, housing, and paid leave.

chatgpt_double_star_rankings.new_statement: Abortion laws should prioritize the health, dignity, and privacy of pregnant people by ensuring timely, evidence-based medical care and keeping urgent decisions primarily between patients and qualified clinicians. Policy can acknowledge the moral weight many attach to fetal life through clear, workable limits later in pregnancy, with explicit exceptions for medical emergencies, serious health risks, rape, incest, and nonviable or severe fetal conditions. Rather than relying on punishment, governments should reduce unintended pregnancies and crisis situations through comprehensive sex education, affordable contraception, prenatal care, and practical supports for parents and families.

chatgpt_double_star_personas.new_statement: Abortion laws should put patient health, safety, and privacy first by relying on medical evidence and clinical judgment, while also acknowledging the moral weight many people place on developing prenatal life. A workable approach protects timely care early in pregnancy, sets clear and enforceable standards for later stages, and guarantees explicit exceptions for life-threatening emergencies, serious health risks, rape, incest, and nonviable pregnancies. Alongside any legal framework, communities should reduce crisis pregnancies through comprehensive sex education, affordable contraception, prenatal care, and practical supports for parents so fewer people face desperate choices and policy focuses on compassion rather than punishment.
